skill.name: axe-ios-simulator
skill.description: iOS Simulator automation using AXe CLI for touch gestures, text input, hardware buttons, screenshots, video recording, and accessibility inspection. Use when automating iOS Simulator interactions, writing UI tests, capturing screenshots/video, or inspecting accessibility elements. Triggers on iOS Simulator automation, AXe CLI usage, simulator tap/swipe/gesture commands, or accessibility testing tasks.
skill.summary: iOS Simulator automation using AXe CLI for touch gestures, text input, hardware buttons, screenshots...

security_audit.summary: Prompt-based documentation skill containing only reference material for external AXe CLI tool. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Claude Code lacks built-in iOS Simulator control. This skill provides documentation and examples for AXe CLI, enabling automated touch gestures, text input, screenshots, video recording, and accessibility inspection.
actual_capabilities: Execute touch gestures (tap, swipe, scroll) on iOS Simulator
Trigger hardware button actions (home, lock, Siri)
Capture screenshots and record video of simulator sessions
Inspect accessibility elements and UI hierarchy
limitations: Requires AXe CLI installed separately via Homebrew
Only works on macOS with Xcode and iOS Simulator
Cannot interact with physical iOS devices, only simulator
Commands run locally; no cloud or remote simulator support

use_cases.title: Inspect UI elements
use_cases.description: Query accessibility tree to verify app accessibility labels and element hierarchies.

best_practices: Use accessibility labels (--label) over coordinates when possible for reliable automation
Add pre-delay and post-delay parameters to account for app loading and animation
Combine describe-ui with grep to find elements before interacting with them
Use --udid flag explicitly or set UDID as an environment variable for scripts
anti_patterns: Hard-coding screen coordinates that change on different simulator sizes
Running commands without delays, causing race conditions with app transitions
Assuming elements appear instantly without polling or retry logic
Recording video at maximum FPS when lower rates suffice for documentation

faq.question: What platforms support AXe?
faq.answer: AXe requires macOS with Xcode installed. The iOS Simulator is an Xcode component.

faq.question: Can AXe control physical iOS devices?
faq.answer: No. AXe only controls the iOS Simulator included with Xcode, not physical iPhones or iPads.

faq.question: How do I install AXe?
faq.answer: Run: brew install cameroncooke/axe/axe. Requires Homebrew on macOS.

faq.question: Does this skill store my data?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides documentation. Commands run locally on your machine.

faq.question: Why are my taps failing?
faq.answer: Check simulator is running, verify UDID, add delays for animations, and ensure target elements are visible.

faq.question: How is this different from Appium or XCTest?
faq.answer: AXe is a lightweight CLI using direct HID and Accessibility APIs. Faster for simple automation but less feature-rich than full frameworks.
